FieldValue.Value: Sarcoma: proportion of patients with extremity soft tissue sarcoma who are clinically staged using tumour node metastases (TNM) staging system prior to definitive treatment.
NHS Scotland, Scottish Cancer Taskforce. Sarcoma clinical quality performance indicators. Edinburgh (Scotland): Healthcare Improvement Scotland; 2016 May 20. 33 p. [30 references]
Clinical Quality Measures: Process
Does not apply to this measure

This measure is used to assess the proportion of patients with extremity soft tissue sarcoma who are clinically staged using tumour node metastases (TNM) staging system prior to definitive treatment.

Note from the National Quality Measures Clearinghouse: This measure is part of the Cancer Quality Performance Indicators (QPIs) collection. For more information, including a complete list of QPI measure sets, please visit the Healthcare Improvement Scotland Web site.

Staging has an important role in determining the most effective treatment for soft tissue sarcoma and provides information on prognosis (Ipach et al., 2012; American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002; Trojani et al., 1984; European Sarcoma Network Working Group [ESMO], 2012).

Clinical staging should follow the principles of tumour node metastases (TNM) classification; this aids the determination of prognosis and choice of therapy (The Royal College of Pathologists, 2014).
American Joint Committee on Cancer. Soft tissue sarcoma. In: Greene FL, Page DL, Fleming ID, et al., editor(s). AJCC cancer staging manual. Sixth edition. New York (NY): Springer; 2002. p. 193-7.

European Sarcoma Network Working Group (ESMO). Soft tissue and visceral sarcomas: ESMO clinical practice guidelines for diagnosis, treatment and follow-up. Ann Oncol. 2012 Oct;23 Suppl 7:vii92-9. PubMed
Ipach I, Wingert T, Kunze B, Kluba T. Oncological outcome and prognostic factors in the therapy of soft tissue sarcoma of the extremities. Orthop Rev (Pavia). 2012 Nov 13;4(4):e34. PubMed
NHS Scotland, Scottish Cancer Taskforce. Sarcoma clinical quality performance indicators. Edinburgh (Scotland): Healthcare Improvement Scotland; 2016 May 20. 33 p. [30 references]
The Royal College of Pathologists. Dataset for cancer histopathology reporting of soft tissue sarcomas. London (UK): The Royal College of Pathologists; 2014.

Trojani M, Contesso G, Coindre JM, Rouesse J, Bui NB, de Mascarel A, Goussot JF, David M, Bonichon F, Lagarde C. Soft-tissue sarcomas of adults; study of pathological prognostic variables and definition of a histopathological grading system. Int J Cancer. 1984 Jan 15;33(1):37-42. PubMed
Extremity soft tissue sarcoma; tumour node metastases (TNM) staging system
All patients with extremity soft tissue sarcoma (see the related "Denominator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

Number of patients with extremity soft tissue sarcoma who are clinically staged using tumour node metastases (TNM) staging system prior to definitive treatment (see the related "Numerator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

Field.Name: Type of Evidence Supporting the Criterion of Quality for the Measure

FieldValue.Value: A clinical practice guideline or other peer-reviewed synthesis of the clinical research evidence
A formal consensus procedure, involving experts in relevant clinical, methodological, public health and organizational sciences
One or more research studies published in a National Library of Medicine (NLM) indexed, peer-reviewed journal

Field.Name: Additional Information Supporting Need for the Measure

FieldValue.Value: Unspecified

The collection of data is piloted on a small number of patient records using a paper data collection form produced by Information Services Division (ISD). The aim is to identify any anomalies or difficulties with data collection prior to full implementation. At least one NHS board in each Regional Cancer Network participates in the pilot.

Field.Name: Allowance for Patient or Population Factors

FieldValue.Value: not defined yet
not defined yet

Target: 95%

The tolerance within this target accounts for the fact that some patients may present with very advanced disease therefore may not be fit for investigation and/or treatment. It also accounts for emergency situations.

The Cancer Quality Performance Indicators (QPIs) will be kept under regular review and be responsive to changes in clinical practice and emerging evidence. Formal reviews are conducted every 3 years and baseline checks each year.
